entry.title: SQL Anywhere 17 Installation Issue: "This file could not be found: sqlcentral1700.jar"
entry.content:
Hi all, 

I am running into issues downloading SAP SQL Anywhere. After installing it on my Windows-based server, when I click on SQL Central, I get the following error message: "This file could not be found: sqlcentral1700.jar". 

I looked into the installed files, and the file it cannot locate is in a folder called "Java" in the SQL Anywhere 17 folder, so I am not sure why I am running into this error and why it says it cannot find this file. Please advise. 

Many thanks, 

Jules

entry.title: Re: ABAP RAP: Execute Business Object Interface from action
entry.content:
Hello @Andre_Fischer  @ChristianLopez , I’m also very interested in this topic.

I’m not sure I understand how the improvement mentioned in the roadmap relates to Christian Lopez’s issue. I’ve developed a similar application (also using I_MaterialDocumentTP), and in my case, the messages are reflected in the UI without any problem.

The real challenge is that these messages are not tied to a specific table row. For example, if my action creates one material document per row, I want to know which row produced which success or error message when the action is executed on multiple rows. This feels like a very basic requirement, and I don’t understand why it’s so complicated to handle properly.

I haven’t tried the Background Processing Framework or job-based workarounds, but I’m not even sure they would work, since material document creation is always tricky due to commit handling (which, fortunately, is managed correctly by the RAP Business Object I_MaterialDocumentTP—a pleasant surprise). You’ve helped in the past to retrieve the created material document ID (which is also tricky but doable). However, as I can see in this GitHub repository, errors are simply not handled in SAP’s examples.

https://github.com/SAP-samples/abap-platform-rap-workshops/blob/main/rap6xx/rap610/exercises/ex4/README.md

entry.title: Re: SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC) – All You Need to Know
entry.content:
I have a customer asking a question regarding BIC codes needed? They currently have 3, can they add 2 more? Here the their rationale for this:

The team is considering the option of asking SWIFT for 2 additional BIC Codes (we currently have 3, one per Region, the idea would be to add 1 new for Saudi and 1 for EMEA/Asia). This will benefit the project in different ways: faster implementation by migrating bank by bank instead of Region by Region, allowing Saudi to keep manual transactions through keeping the old BIC code, among others.

I'm not sure how to advise. Perhaps it's best if they talk directly to MBC Technical Engineer? They were hoping to discuss this with someone with expertise before submitting the SR to build TEST connectivity.

entry.title: From Docs to Dialogue: Unlock AI Self-Service Learning for Your Internal Teams
entry.content:
From Docs to Dialogue: Unlock AI Self-Service Learning for Your Internal Teams

  • Every organization wants onboarding to be faster, clearer, and less dependent on tribal knowledge.
  • NotebookLM enables the conversion of trusted product documentation and internal project artifacts into an AI-based conversational resource that employees can engage with naturally, as if they were chatting with their most knowledgeable coworker. Instead of searching across files, PDFs, and web pages, teams can ask direct questions about product behavior, setup requirements, and configuration considerations, and instantly turn answers into internal training materials.
  • This AI-driven approach
    • scales knowledge without replacing expertise
    • streamlines learning without adding process overhead
    • helps organizations build deeper product fluency internally
 

Table of Contents

  • Benefits & Use Cases
  • Gathering Trusted Knowledge
  • SAP Product Documentation
  • Other relevant documentation
  • Getting Started with NotebookLM
  • Chatbot-Driven Learning
  • Generating Internal Training Assets
  • Audio Overview: podcast interview for auditory learning
  • Infographic: a one-stop shop PDF for visual learning
  • Video Overview: a training video for visual learning
  • Flashcards and Quizzes: A hands-on tool for your team to learn
  • Best Practices
  • End-to-End overview
  • A real-world example, see NotebookLM in action
  • Prompt
  • Infographic
  • Video Overview
  • Chatbot Response
  • Considerations & Final Takeaways

Benefits & Use Cases

  • Faster employee ramp-up by turning existing SAP Documentation into a conversational AI learning environment
  • Instant answers for distributed teams across roles, experience levels, and time zones
  • Improved configuration confidence through real-time dialogue with authoritative sources
  • Consistent onboarding experiences that reduce knowledge gaps between new hires
  • Rapid training asset creation (FAQs, slide outlines, learning summaries) generated directly from source material
  • Search less, learn more—teams ask questions instead of digging across files and folders.
  • More informed internal experts because foundational questions get answered efficiently and consistently
  • Support interactions become more efficient and solution-focused when they happen, backed by deeper internal product fluency.

Gathering Trusted Knowledge

To begin using NoteBookLM as your AI Self-Service learning tool, you must first gather all of the relevant knowledge on the specific SAP product you are looking to focus on. These will become your sources within NotebookLM and will act as the knowledge base that NotebookLM uses as it guides your 

The free version of NotebookLM is limited to 50 sources, so please consider this as you capture your list of sources

SAP Product Documentation

https://help.sap.com/docs/ contains all relevant product documentation for your SAP products and is the best place to start gathering the content you need. 

  1. Go to SAP Help   
  2. Search for the specific SAP product you are looking to hone in on and then click on the Suggested Product that most aligns with your search.   
    Example: SAP Business Network for Procurement 
  3. In the bottom right corner of the top banner, click Download PDF 
  4. Select all relevant options from the pop-up page, then click Download at the bottom of the page 

Other relevant documentation

In addition to the standard SAP Product Documentation, you can gather information from various sources, including webpages, documents, PDFs, video transcripts, and raw text.

Consult with your internal security and compliance teams to review the NotebookLM terms of service before interacting with any non-public documentation 

  • SOPs (standard operating procedures) for business processes 
  • configuration specifications and customization designs
  • Project planning and scope documentation 
  • public-facing / external blogs or training content on the product or business process (YouTube videos, Blogs, industry journals, etc.) 
  • Product demos or training recording transcripts 
  • Company branding information 

Getting Started with NotebookLM

Now that you have all your sources prepared, you can begin uploading them to NotebookLM. 

  1. Open NotebookLM and complete the onboarding process to create a free account. This will be tied to your Gmail/Google account. Please consult your internal teams regarding any enterprise plans or privacy concerns.
  2. Create a new notebook, selecting the + Create New button
  3. Upload the files that you captured in the previous step by clicking Upload Files
  4. Allow your sources to load. Once complete, you should see all your sources displayed in the left panel.
  5. To share your notebook with other colleagues, you can click the Share button in the top right of the page. 

Chatbot-Driven Learning

In the middle section of the page, you can interact with the notebook via Chat, as if you were talking with a product expert. 

  • NotebookLM will then use AI to develop an answer, intentionally prioritizing your repository of sources to provide the proper context and deliver the best answer to your question.
  • Within the AI-generated response, you will notice that small numbers with circles around them are displayed throughout the answer. You can click these, and then the left panel will take you directly into the specific source document where it pulled that part of the answer from
  • For a more visual approach, you can also click the Mind Map option in the Studio panel. Once generated, you can click to view a visual representation of the sources you uploaded. As you click deeper into the mind map, the chat will auto-update and help kick-start a conversation you can use to drill down into a specific topic area. 

As with any AI LLM-based tool, results may vary and should be reviewed in detail by your teams for accuracy. 

You can continue your conversation with the AI chatbot by asking it

  • additional clarifying questions specific to your needs
  • reframing your question in more complete wording to provide more context
  • to drill down deeper into specific areas of its response 
  • to drill down deeper into specific documents/sources 
  • Additional documentation 

Generating Internal Training Assets

The right portion of the page, called Studio, will include options (depending on your plan) to generate content tailored to your team's training and enablement needs. 

For each option in the studio, click the Pencil icon to customize the result by providing a prompt that guides the studio's content generation and is tailored to your needs.

  • If you do not click the pencil, it will auto-generate based on all your sources. Depending on the size and scope of your sources, the output may be too high-level without a custom prompt provided. 

Each Studio option may also provide its own set of configuration toggles in addition to a custom prompt.

Each option also includes a Download option, allowing you to export any generated content to your internal libraries or training tools. 

Audio Overview: podcast interview for auditory learning

The audio overview option generates a one-on-one podcast interview between two people who discuss your sources and/or your custom prompt. You can use this to create targeted podcasts that dive into specific areas, then include them in onboarding materials for teams who prefer an Auditory format. 

*Pro Tip: upload your own transcript or outline of how you would like the conversation to go. This will help guide the model to create an interview that covers the areas you consider essential, rather than guessing what to highlight. 

*Pro Tip: When providing your custom prompt, include specifics as to how you would like the tone of the speakers to be. By default, the podcasts may seem a bit exaggerated at times. You can ask the prompt to use more normal and realistic tones and/or ask it to avoid certain words like "massive" or "huge", for example 

Infographic: a one-stop shop PDF for visual learning

The infographic will create a one-pager PDF with AI-generated visuals that provide a more "connect the dots" overview of the sources. It will start with a high-level overview that connects all sources (similar to a Mind Map), but if you provide a specific prompt, it can also provide a more refined overview of that topic area. 

*Pro Tip: check the visual for any discrepancies. If you see issues, recreate the infographic by changing your custom prompt to call out the mistake you want to avoid. The more specifics you provide, the better 

*Pro Tip: In your custom prompt, call out the audience that will be consuming the graphic itself. It can tailor the messaging and graphic style to better suit that audience. You can also ask it to reference a branding source if you have uploaded one that includes logos, color schemes, etc. 

Video Overview: a training video for visual learning

The video overview will provide a more traditional training format, with one speaker presenting the topic while an AI-generated video plays in the background. The video will resemble a PowerPoint presentation. You can use this to create a high-level video overview of the sources, or to provide a custom prompt that goes into one area in more detail. 

*Pro Tip: The graphics or numbers on the video itself need to be reviewed for accuracy. If you see discrepancies between what is displayed and what is mentioned in the video, you will need to refine your custom prompt and regenerate the video to close the gap. The more specific you are (e.g., an outline or script and dos and don'ts), the better the results you will get. You are unable to edit the video itself or adjust the slides/visuals after it is generated 

Flashcards and Quizzes: A hands-on tool for your team to learn 

The Flashcards option searches for primary and recurring keywords and definitions in your sources and automatically generates flashcards to help learners study/memorize key terms. 

The Quiz option will also search for primary and recurring keywords across the sources and generate an interactive question-and-answer quiz. 

*Quizzes cannot be downloaded externally 

Best Practices

  • Depending on your sources and the sheer volume of data within the notebook, the AI Models can and will hallucinate. Having detailed, specific prompts to guide each conversation or studio creation toward a specific goal will produce the best results. It is better to break your content needs into smaller groupings with detailed prompts than to blindly ask it to create high-level overviews. 
  • Be sure to consult with your internal privacy and compliance teams before uploading any non-public information into NotebookLM. As a general rule, only upload publicly available content to NotebookLM. 
  • YouTube videos can be effective at providing an additional perspective through a more expert-focused, human-guided lens on your dataset of sources. Collect long-form YouTube interviews with experts in your area and upload the URLs as additional sources to your notebook. 
  • Create your own scripts or outlines beforehand and provide those to the chat or studio in addition to your primary ask it. This will help ensure it follows the correct path you are looking for and does not hallucinate. You can also use other LLMs or AI Chatbots to help you come up with ideas and draft a high-level script or outline to follow. 
  • If you share your notebook with end users, ensure they understand that chatbot results must be reviewed and refined to provide guidance that helps kick-start an investigation into a topic. End users should be wary of copying/pasting AI-generated content externally. 

End-to-End overview

Find your product at SAP Help

Download the SAP product documentation to PDF 

Create a notebook and upload files to NotebookLM 

Observe your sources and begin interacting with the chatbot & studio

A real-world example, see NotebookLM in action

The SAP Business Network for Procurement is used globally to connect buyers and suppliers and enable interaction and transactions. This results in a variety of country-specific invoicing laws and portals that vary by country. The application itself includes standard invoicing features and built-in support for various country-specific E-Invoicing mandates. 

In this example, we will investigate how we can learn more about this topic using NotebookLM with a single prompt to generate a text answer, an infographic, and a video overview file. 

Prompt

I want to learn more about e-invoicing and country-specific invoicing rules within the SBN for the Procurement application. My team has a basic understanding of the core SBN Procurement flows, but is seeking more guidance on the e-invoicing and country-specific invoicing logic and features within the product. Can you help produce content that clarifies this for us and explains the topic in detail as it relates to the larger product? Id like to know what is supported in the app, how i would interact with these features, if there are any specific setup or customization requirements to use this, and a list of which countries are currently supported. 
The audience here is a group of corporate employees who know procurement as a whole. Keep things professional and short/sweet. Don't use any exaggerations and don't overhype with any big, bold words. Use simpler, down-to-earth professional wording. 

Infographic

Video Overview

 

Chatbot Response

Here is an overview of how SAP Business Network (SBN) handles e-invoicing and country-specific compliance.

In the context of the Procurement application, e-invoicing on SBN goes beyond emailing a PDF. The system uses structured data (cXML) to validate invoices against your business rules and the legal regulations of the supplier’s country before the invoice reaches your internal systems.

The core feature that manages this is Country/Region-Based Invoice Rules. When a supplier submits an invoice, SBN detects the originating country based on the supplier’s VAT ID prefix or address, then applies a specific set of validation rules that override default transaction rules. This ensures that suppliers in different countries — for example Italy vs the United States — see different required fields and localized behaviors.

The platform supports several compliance models depending on the region.

For VAT-regulated regions, particularly in the EU, Australia, and Canada, SBN enforces required tax information such as VAT IDs, supply dates, tax breakdowns, and local currency requirements.

In countries using government clearance models, where the government must approve an invoice before the buyer receives it, SBN integrates directly with national invoice platforms. Examples include KSeF (Poland), SDI (Italy), and the E-Invoice system (India).

SBN automatically applies digital signatures to invoices for many countries to ensure document integrity and authenticity.

The system also converts standard cXML invoice data into legally mandated formats required by specific governments or networks. Examples include FatturaPA (Italy) and Peppol UBL (supported in countries such as Belgium and Singapore).

Buyers interact with these features primarily through configuration rather than manual invoice transactions.

To configure rules, buyers navigate to Country-Based Invoice Rules within the Administration and Configuration settings. Here, countries can be activated and compliance requirements can be enabled or disabled, such as requiring suppliers to send tax invoice documents.

Buyers can monitor invoice submission status in their inbox. For government-connected countries, invoice history will include status updates showing government validation progress and results.

Buyers can also generate compliance visibility through built-in reporting. One example is the Supplier Legal Profile report, which shows which suppliers have completed the required tax compliance setup for their country or region.

Suppliers see a dynamic invoice creation experience based on their country. During invoice creation, suppliers are shown required local tax fields based on their location — for example GST IDs and HSN codes in India, or Stamp Duty fields in Italy.

Suppliers in countries with strict mandates must complete a Legal Profile or Country Configuration in their account settings. This is where they enter tax registration numbers and upload any required digital certificates or identifiers for government or network compliance.

To enable these features in an SBN Buyer account, buyers must update Default Transaction Rules to allow country-based invoice rules to take precedence instead of being ignored.

Buyers must also add and activate the specific countries they trade with in Country-Based Invoice Rules.

For countries that route invoices through external networks like Peppol, buyers must register their Peppol Participant ID or equivalent identifier in their profile so suppliers can send invoices successfully.

For countries where SBN retrieves invoices directly from government portals (inbound invoice flow), buyers must configure External Document Service settings to establish a connection with the national tax authority. Examples include Poland and Romania.

SBN supports country-specific compliance logic, VAT validation, or government integration for the following countries.

Americas: Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, United States.

Asia/Pacific: Australia, China, India, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand.

Europe: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, Ukraine, United Kingdom.

Middle East/Africa: Israel, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, UAE.

Considerations & Final Takeaways

Every organization wants onboarding to be faster, clearer, and built on trusted knowledge rather than fragmented internal know-how. NotebookLM enables teams to convert authoritative product documentation, SOPs, configuration specs, SOWs, demos, and project artifacts into a secure AI-powered conversational resource that employees can interact with naturally—like chatting with their most knowledgeable coworker. Instead of manually searching across files and web pages, teams can ask direct questions about product capabilities, setup requirements, and configuration considerations, then instantly convert those answers into internal enablement assets such as training outlines, FAQs, flashcards, infographics, and learning summaries. When setting up your NotebookLM hub, prioritize source quality, clear document labeling, and intentional prompting during training to reduce ambiguity and improve accuracy. This approach scales product fluency across teams, streamlines learning without adding process overhead, and creates more confident, self-sufficient users—while ensuring that expert conversations, when needed, are informed, efficient, and outcome-driven.

entry.title: Simplifying Time Series Analytics with Unified Time Series Interface
entry.content:
Time series analysis is fundamental in industries ranging from retail to finance, helping businesses forecast trends, predict anomalies, and optimize operations. Traditional approaches, however, often require complex preprocessing, data conversion, and algorithm selection, posing challenges for less technical users.

To address these issues, SAP HANA Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) has introduced a unified interface for time series algorithms. Following the successful implementation of its unified classification and regression interfaces, this update aims to make time series analysis more efficient and user-friendly.

In this blog post, we explore the latest features of this unified interface and showcase an example to illustrate its usage.

Key Highlights

Let’s dive into new interface's key features in detail:

Unified Workflow

The unified interface streamlines the management of PAL algorithms by providing a standardized structure for invoking them. This simplifies parameter handling and data preparation for individual algorithms, enhancing efficiency and ease of use. Supported algorithms include Additive Model Time Series Analysis (AMTSA), Auto Regressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA), Bayesian Structural Time Series (BSTS), and Exponential Smoothing (SMOOTH).

Automatic Timestamp Conversion

The datasets of different time series analysis tasks can have diverse time formats, therefore automatic timestamp conversion is introduced in new unified interface. This feature automatically detects and converts between integer timepoints and timestamp types. To convert timepoints to timestamps, users must define START_POINT and INTERVAL. INTERVAL represents the spacing between timestamps, measured in the smallest unit of the target type (TARGET_TYPE). For instance, if the target type is DAYDATE and a weekly interval is desired, the INTERVAL value would be set to 7. Conversely, converting timestamps to timepoints is automated, with the system generating consecutive integers based on input timestamps. However, the input timestamps should be evenly spaced for this conversion to function effectively.

Pivoted Input Data Format Support

Traditionally, additional steps are required to transform the pivoted data into a usable format. To simplify this data preparation process, the new unified interface directly supports pivoted input data formats. This feature is particularly beneficial for complex, multidimensional time series data. The structure of input data is defined in the metadata table,  as illustrated below.

CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_META_DATA_TBL (
    "VARIABLE_NAME" NVARCHAR (50),
    "VARIABLE_TYPE" NVARCHAR (50)
);
INSERT INTO PAL_META_DATA_TBL VALUES ('TIMESTAMP', 'CONTINUOUS');
INSERT INTO PAL_META_DATA_TBL VALUES ('Y', 'TARGET');

Massive Mode Capability

When dealing with vast datasets, users can leverage "massive mode" in unified interface. This mode enables algorithms to process multiple datasets simultaneously, with each dataset being executed independently and in parallel. To learn more about massive mode, visit the page on Massive Execution of PAL Functions.

Example

Let’s demonstrate the new interface with an example. Note that the code provided is purely for illustrative purposes and is not intended for production use.

The dataset is the Beijing PM2.5 data from the UCI Machine Learning Repository. It comprises hourly recordings of PM2.5 levels (airborne particles with aerodynamic diameters less than 2.5 μm) collected by the US Embassy in Beijing between January 1, 2010, and December 31, 2014. Additionally, meteorological data from Beijing Capital International Airport is included. The objective is to predict PM2.5 concentrations using various input features.

This dataset contains 43,824 rows and 11 columns. During preprocessing, the year, month, day, and hour columns were merged into a single 'date' column, and rows with missing values were addressed. The restructured dataset included the following 9 columns.

date: Timestamp of the record

pollution: PM2.5 concentration (ug/m^3)

dew: Dew Point

temp: Temperature

press: Pressure (hPa)

wnd_dir: Combined wind direction

wnd_spd: Cumulated wind speed (m/s)

snow: Cumulated hours of snow

rain: Cumulated hours of rain

To make it more manageable for demonstration purposes, we selected the first 1,000 instances. From this selection, we allocated 990 instances to the training set and reserved the final 10 for the testing set. Here's a glimpse at the first five rows of the training set.

Once the data is loaded, the model can be trained, and results can be obtained using the following annotated SQL script.

--########## COLUMN TABLE CREATION ##########
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_PARAMETER_TBL__0 ("PARAM_NAME" NVARCHAR(256), "INT_VALUE" INTEGER, "DOUBLE_VALUE" DOUBLE, "STRING_VALUE" NVARCHAR(1000));
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_MODEL_TBL__0 ("INDEX" NVARCHAR (50), "CONTENT" NCLOB);
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_STATISTICS_TBL__0 ("NAME" NVARCHAR (50), "VALUE_1" DOUBLE, "VALUE_2" DOUBLE, "VALUE_3" DOUBLE, "VALUE_4" DOUBLE, "VALUE_5" DOUBLE, "REASON" NVARCHAR (50));
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_DECOMPOSE_TBL__0 ("TIME_STAMP" NVARCHAR (50), "TREND" DOUBLE, "SEASONAL" DOUBLE, "REGRESSION" DOUBLE, "RANDOM" DOUBLE);
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_PLACE_HOLDER_TBL__0 ("OBJECT" NVARCHAR (10), "KEY" NVARCHAR (10), "VALUE" NVARCHAR (10));
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_PREDICT_PARAMETER_TBL__0 ("PARAM_NAME" NVARCHAR(256), "INT_VALUE" INTEGER, "DOUBLE_VALUE" DOUBLE, "STRING_VALUE" NVARCHAR(1000));
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_PREDICT_RESULT_TBL__0 ("TIME_STAMP" NVARCHAR (50), "FORECAST" DOUBLE, "VALUE_1" DOUBLE, "VALUE_2" DOUBLE, "VALUE_3" DOUBLE, "VALUE_4" DOUBLE, "VALUE_5" DOUBLE);
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_PREDICT_DECOMPOSITION_TBL__0 ("TIME_STAMP" NVARCHAR (50), "VALUE_1" DOUBLE, "VALUE_2" NCLOB, "VALUE_3" NCLOB, "VALUE_4" NCLOB, "VALUE_5" NCLOB);
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_PREDICT_PLACE_HOLDER_TBL__0 ("OBJECT" NVARCHAR (50), "KEY" NVARCHAR (50), "VALUE" NVARCHAR (50));

--########## TABLE INSERTS ##########
-- The training data is stored in PAL_DATA_TBL__0, and the prediction data in PAL_PREDICT_DATA_TBL__0.
--########## PAL_PARAMETER_TBL__0 DATA INSERTION ##########
-- Specify algorithm type, 0: AMTSA, 1: ARIMA, 2: BSTS, 3: SMOOTH
INSERT INTO PAL_PARAMETER_TBL__0 VALUES ('FUNCTION', 0, NULL, NULL);

--########## UNIFIED INTERFACE FOR TIME SERIES CALL ##########
DO BEGIN
  lt_data = SELECT * FROM PAL_DATA_TBL__0;
  lt_param = SELECT * FROM PAL_PARAMETER_TBL__0;
  CALL _SYS_AFL.PAL_UNIFIED_TIMESERIES (:lt_data, :lt_param, lt_model, lt_stat, lt_decom, lt_ph);
  lt_pdata = SELECT * FROM PAL_PREDICT_DATA_TBL__0;
  lt_pparam = SELECT * FROM PAL_PREDICT_PARAMETER_TBL__0;
  CALL _SYS_AFL.PAL_UNIFIED_TIMESERIES_PREDICT (:lt_pdata, :lt_model, :lt_pparam, lt_result, lt_decomp, lt_pph);
  INSERT INTO PAL_PREDICT_RESULT_TBL__0 SELECT * FROM :lt_result;
  INSERT INTO PAL_PREDICT_DECOMPOSITION_TBL__0 SELECT * FROM :lt_decomp;
END;

--########## SELECT * TABLES ##########
SELECT * FROM PAL_PREDICT_RESULT_TBL__0;
SELECT * FROM PAL_PREDICT_DECOMPOSITION_TBL__0;

--########## TABLES CLEANUP ##########
DROP TABLE PAL_PARAMETER_TBL__0;
DROP TABLE PAL_MODEL_TBL__0;
DROP TABLE PAL_STATISTICS_TBL__0;
DROP TABLE PAL_DECOMPOSE_TBL__0;
DROP TABLE PAL_PLACE_HOLDER_TBL__0;
DROP TABLE PAL_PREDICT_PARAMETER_TBL__0;
DROP TABLE PAL_PREDICT_RESULT_TBL__0;
DROP TABLE PAL_PREDICT_DECOMPOSITION_TBL__0;
DROP TABLE PAL_PREDICT_PLACE_HOLDER_TBL__0;

You can view the model, prediction results, and decomposition in the output tables. Below are illustrative snapshots of the output tables.

The composition of the resulting tables depends on the selected algorithm. For AMTSA, the result table includes the predicted values along with the lower and upper bounds of the uncertainty intervals. Additionally, the decomposition table provides various components, such as trend, seasonality, and others.

Summary

The unified interface is introduced to simplify the usage of PAL algorithms. This blog post highlights the key features addressing challenges in time series analysis, such as varied time formats, pivoted data structures, and handling large data volumes. This new interface makes it easier for users to unlock the potential of their temporal data.

 

Recent topics on HANA machine learning:

Comprehensive Guide to MLTrack in SAP HANA Cloud: End-to-End Machine Learning Experiment Tracking

New Machine Learning and AI features in SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q2

New Machine Learning and AI features in SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q1

entry.title: Re: Redirect output item in S4 Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi @emmanuelm1 ,

The Manage Output Items app provides a central overview of the outputs that are sent through various channels, together with their processing status. It allows users to monitor and process multiple output items simultaneously, mainly for error analysis and corrective actions.

With this app, you can:

  • Identify individual failed output items
  • Analyze the root cause of output errors (via Log)
  • Mass process output items
  • Send output items
  • Duplicate completed output items
  • Retry sending output items
  • Set output items to Completed

However, changing the printer is not supported in this app. When an output item is duplicated, it is created with the same original output parameters, including the print queue and printer. Therefore, printer reassignment at output-item level is not possible.

 

Recommended Approaches

Variant A — Printer determination via business rules (Based on SAP standard behaviour and SAP Note 2757763 recommendations)

Use Output Parameter Determination (BRF+) to automatically determine the printer based on business-relevant criteria, such as:

  • Warehouse number
  • Storage location
  • Shipping point
  • Plant
  • Etc.

You can then define separate output parameter rules, for example:

  • Warehouse A → Printer A
  • Warehouse B → Printer B

During the transition period:

  1. Ensure that deliveries are assigned to the correct warehouse or storage location.
  2. The printer is selected automatically by the output determination logic.

 

Variant B — Create separate output types

Create two distinct output types:

  • Output Type A → Printer Site 1
  • Output Type B → Printer Site 2

Then:

  • Assign the output type based on the warehouse or location

entry.title: Package Change and ProcessingMode Unification for Standard OData Service
entry.content:
We would like to request your guidance on the recommended procedures for changing the package and unifying the ProcessingMode of the standard OData service API_PROD_ORDER_CONFIRMATION_2_SRV.

[Current Situation]

  • Target OData Service: API_PROD_ORDER_CONFIRMATION_2_SRV (Standard Service)
  • Package Inconsistency: Some objects of this OData service are currently assigned to the $TMP package (only on the development system).
  • ProcessingMode Discrepancy: The ProcessingMode for API_PROD_ORDER_CONFIRMATION_2_SRV is not consistent across our environments (Development, Test, Staging, Production). Specifically, it is Routing-based only on the Development system.
  • Note: Currently, no system errors or service operation issues have arisen due to these inconsistencies. However, we aim to unify these settings across all our systems.

[Questions/Consultation Items]

  1. Standard OData Service Package Change: Is changing the package of objects belonging to a standard OData service like API_PROD_ORDER_CONFIRMATION_2_SRV a recommended practice by SAP?

    • If not recommended, could you suggest alternative approaches (e.g., using a custom service, applying an SAP Note fix)?
    • If recommended or unavoidable, please provide specific guidance on the procedure (e.g., how to ensure no objects are missed, potential risks, points to consider).

  2. ProcessingMode Unification: To unify the ProcessingMode to Co-deployed only, are there any considerations or specific steps beyond the package change that we should be aware of?

  3. Object Identification: Could you recommend the most reliable methods or tools to comprehensively identify all related objects for this OData service? (We are currently investigating using transactions like /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE, /n/IWBEP/REG_MODEL, /n/IWBEP/REG_SERVICE, SEGW, SE24, and SICF.)

We appreciate your time and kind assistance in this matter.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Package Change and ProcessingMode Unification for Sta...
entry.content:
1. Standard OData Service Package Change

In general, SAP does not recommend changing the package assignment of objects belonging to standard SAP OData services, such as API_PROD_ORDER_CONFIRMATION_2_SRV. Standard objects should remain in their SAP-delivered packages to ensure compatibility with future upgrades, support packages, and SAP Notes.

If objects are assigned to $TMP in the development system, they are usually customer-specific extensions or locally generated artifacts. In this case, only custom or extension objects (for example, MPC_EXT/DPC_EXT classes or Z implementations) should be reassigned to a transportable Z package via SE80 and transported to the follow-up systems. SAP standard objects should not be repackaged. Reassigning standard objects should only be done if explicitly instructed by SAP (for example, via an SAP Note).

2. ProcessingMode Unification

The ProcessingMode (Routing-based vs. Co-deployed) is a service configuration setting and is independent of package assignment. To unify the ProcessingMode to Co-deployed, you can adjust the setting via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE → Technical Service Settings in each system. If required, the configuration can be transported using a customizing transport. After changing the ProcessingMode, it is recommended to perform cache cleanup and, if applicable, reload the service metadata to ensure consistent behavior.

3. Object Identification

To comprehensively identify all objects related to API_PROD_ORDER_CONFIRMATION_2_SRV, start with /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE to review the registered service and its technical details. Use /IWBEP/REG_SERVICE and /IWBEP/REG_MODEL to identify the associated MPC/DPC and extension classes. SE80 and SE24 can be used to analyze the class hierarchy and package assignments, while SICF helps validate the ICF service configuration. This combination provides reliable coverage of both standard and customer-specific artifacts.

Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Keeping SAP IDs when New SAP Customer ID is used
entry.content:
Regarding to your questions, please kindly refer to KBA 3271534 - Tips for handling migration of users/cases/systems when contracts are moved to a different customer number - SAP for Me

Abstract below information for your reference:

*******************************************************************************************************************************

Can S-user IDs be moved to a different customer number?
No, S-user IDs cannot be moved to a different customer number which is explained in KBA 2423500. After S-user IDs are created, the customer number can never be changed. If users need access to a different customer number, new S-user IDs need to be created (and authorizations provided) under the new customer by that company's administrators. When migration is complete and/or the S-user no longer needs access to the old customer number, the S-user should be deleted from the old customer number. For more information on creating and deleting S-user IDs see KBA 1271482. For assistance, report a case for component XX-SER-FORME.

Can cases be moved to a different customer number?
No, support cases cannot be migrated to the new customer number and will remain under the installation number and customer number where it was created (old customer number). This is mentioned in KBA 2403394.
Tip: If users need to continue working with SAP on a specific case during a migration, a new case should be created under the new customer number along with a message indicating “This is a continuation of case XXXX….” and the S-user can copy the previous details into the new case. For assistance, report a case for component XX-SER-FORME.

******************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************

In summary, the S-users and cases under the old customer account cannot be moved to the new customer account; however, you can still use those S-users under the old customer account to view previous cases.

entry.title: Inquiry: Unexpected "Never" (1) Setting for Purchase Requisition in External Processing Operations
entry.content:
I am writing to request technical assistance regarding an issue where Purchase Requisitions (PR) are not being automatically generated for external operations in some Production Orders.

[Current Configuration]

Control Key (T-code: OP00): Set to '+' (External processing).

Order Type-Dependent Parameters (T-code: OPL8): The "Reservation/Purc. Req." field in the Planning tab is set to '2' (Immediately) for the relevant Plant and Order Type.

[The Issue] Despite the settings above, in our Production system, the "Reservation/Purc. Req." field in the External Processing tab of certain Production Orders is intermittently changed to '1' (Never). This prevents the PR from being created.

[Key Findings]

This issue occurs only for specific orders in the Production environment; we cannot replicate it in the QA environment where it works as expected (Status '2').

Users mentioned they manually adjusted the Component Quantity in the Production Order before the issue occurred. However, testing this scenario in QA still results in successful PR generation.

Once the field is set to '1' (Never), the automatic link to procurement is severed for that specific operation.

[Request] We would like to understand under what specific conditions or system logic the "Reservation/Purc. Req." field in an operation is forcibly changed to '1' (Never), overriding the default configuration in OPL8.

Are there any known SAP Notes, user exits, or specific manual interventions (such as changes in status or components) that could trigger this behavior?

I look forward to your expert guidance.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Asynchronous Logging in SAP API Management
entry.content:
Hi Community,

" The API proxy processes it and immediately sends the response back to the api proxy consumer due to async mode of logging. Logging operations happen separately in the background by queuing messages to JMS for later processing. Background processes handle the actual delivery to Loggly or other logging platforms. If logging fails, it gets retried without impacting the response time."

 

Thanks for your selfless sharing, it really help us a lot.

 

🙂

Regards,

ZFiori.

entry.title: Re: has anyone figured out a report to audit when a cours...
entry.content:
The "Online Item Status" Report (Best for Quick Audits)This is the standard report most admins use to see when content was last touched.

• Where to find it: Go to Learning Administration > Reports > search for "Online Item Status".

Look for the column "User Last Activity." This field captures the exact timestamp of the last time the user launched any content object inside that specific item/course. It is updated every time the content player communicates with the LMS.

entry.title: BAPI_PO_CHANGE can't change quantity
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am currently facing an issue when using BAPI_PO_CHANGE to update the quantity of a Purchase Order item. In some cases, the updated quantity is correctly reflected in ME23N, while in other cases the quantity does not change, even though the BAPI is executed without any error messages.

Below are some details of my implementation:
  • The quantity is passed in POITEM and marked as changed in POITEMX (e.g. quantity = X).
  • The BAPI return table does not contain any error or abort messages.
  • A BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT is executed after calling the BAPI.
  • The PO can be opened in ME23N without any visible error or warning.
However, the update is inconsistent and does not always persist.
Could this behavior be related to:
  • PO release status or approval strategy?
  • Item category or account assignment restrictions?
  • User exits or BAdIs (such as ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST) that may override the quantity?
  • Buffering or timing issues during the update?
I would really appreciate any insights or suggestions on what additional checks or best practices should be applied when handling quantity changes via BAPI_PO_CHANGE.

Thank you very much.

entry.title: Integration Advisor – GS1 XML Messages of the version 2.x series (EAN.UCC)
entry.content:
I am pleased to announce that we have now added older versions (from the 2.x series) of GS1 XML Messages to our predefined Type System content in the Integration Advisor of SAP Integration Suite. In this blog post, I would like to give you a short overview of our new offering.

GS1 XML Messages

The GS1 organization offers the GS1 XML library. This library contains a set of standard messages for GS1 EDI (Electronic Data Interchange) enabling the exchange of transactional information between trading partners. For more background on GS1 XML, you can refer to the GS1 homepage (Link).

Previously, we already offered eight versions (from 3.0 to 3.6) of the newer 3.x series of GS1 XML messages, which were published between 2012 and 2023. For more details, refer to my earlier blog post (Link).

We have learned that the older 2.x series (published between 2006 and 2013) is still in use and that our customers would like to use these versions in Integration Advisor as well. Therefore, we have now added ten additional versions (from 2.0.2 to 2.8) of GS1 XML messages. Incidentally, these messages are sometimes also referred to as EAN.UCC messages. 

The new offering contains a total of 86 messages, such as, order, invoice or despatchAdvice:

Please note that the GS1 organization undertook a major refactoring of their offering starting with version 3.0. (For more background, see this page on the GS1 homepage: Link.) For example, versions 2.x include the message type order (in namespace urn:ean.ucc:order:2), while versions 3.x include the message type orderMessage (in namespace urn:gs1:ecom:order:xsd:3). Although the newer orderMessage is considered the semantic successor of the older order, they are structurally quite different and even come with different message type identifiers and namespaces. As a result, Integration Advisor lists the corresponding message types separately.   

Use of Envelopes

In the 2.x series of GS1 XML messages, the GS1 organization followed the design principle of combining an envelope structure with the business document (message) structure. Unfortunately, the GS1 schema definitions did not include the full envelope specifications, but only fragments of different parts. 

Based on the GS1 Implementation Guide and the original GS1 XML sample payloads, we have derived the allowed variations that were envisioned to be used for exchanging GS1 XML messages. As a result, Integration Advisor provides you with four envelope structures called Envelope1 - Envelope4.

All GS1 XML payloads (of the 2.x series) start with the root node StandardBusinessDocument (from the UN/CEFACT namespace) and always include the StandardBusinessDocumentHeader child node. (Please note the difference compared to the design in the 3.x series: In the latter, the root node is specific for the GS1 business document (like orderMessage or invoiceMessage) and only the child node StandardBusinessDocumentHeader is reused from the UN/CEFACT organization.)

The four envelopes differ in their complexity and flexibility. The simplest Envelope1 just allows you to include one business document, while the most complex Envelope4 provides you with additional hierarchy levels for Message, Transaction, and Document Command. See the table below for an overview of the allowed hierarchy levels in the four envelopes.  

Envelope IDEnvelope NameMessageTransactionCommandBusiness Document
Envelope1Envelope for a 1-level hierarchy   X
Envelope2Envelope for a 2-level hierarchyX  X
Envelope3Envelope for a 3-level hierarchyX XX
Envelope4Envelope for a 4-level hierarchyXXXX

When you create your Message Implementation Guideline (MIG) in Integration Advisor, you can combine a GS1 XML business document (like order or invoice) with one of the four envelopes. If you are in doubt about which envelope to use, simply check a sample payload from your business partner to understand the required hierarchy levels for your business transaction. 

The next screenshot shows a MIG in Integration Advisor that combines the order Message (marked by the green box) with the Envelope4 envelope (marked by the blue box):

Please see this blog post (Link) to learn more about envelope handling in Integration Advisor.

For the very rare case that you need a special envelope structure that is not part of our standard content, you should proceed as follows: In Integration Advisor, create your MIG without an envelope. In your Integration Flow (in Cloud Integration), use a Content Modifier flow step to remove the envelope parts (for the inbound direction) or to add the envelope parts (for the outbound direction).

A few more technical notes for the older GS1 XML Messages

Standard content and GDSN content:

  • Our delivery includes the official versions from GS1 International, namely versions 2.0.2, 2.1, 2.1.1, 2.3, 2.4, 2.5, and 2.6 (see also Link).
  • Additionally, the GS1 GDSN Working Group has also published messages for use cases related to the Global Data Synchronization Network (GDSN). These messages can be found in versions 2.0.2, 2.2, 2.3, 2.7, and 2.8.

Versioning:

  • In the older 2.x versions, GS1 followed the versioning strategy where a version only contains message types that were updated. For example, message order is included in versions 2.0.2, 2.1, 2.4, 2.5, and 2.6, but is not part of versions 2.1.1, 2.3, 2.7, or 2.8.
  • In contrast, the newer 3.x versions typically include all message types, regardless of whether they have been changed or not. (This is similar to many other B2B Libraries, like cXML or UN/EDIFACT.) 

Codelist support:

  • The GS1 organization has defined codelists for the older GS1 XML messages, and these codelists are part of the GS1 XML Type System content. The codelists and their code values represent the state at the time of publication. (This is similar to many other B2B Libraries.) 
  • Later on, GS1 changed its codelist publication strategy and now offers their codelists as separate content packages, independent of message standards like GS1 EANCOM or GS1 XML. Integration Advisor also provides these reusable GS1 Codelists as a separate Codelist Type System. (See this blog post for more details: Link). As a result, the 3.x versions of GS1 XML no longer include codelists. but instead refer to the separate GS1 Codelist collection.
  • If you prefer using a newer version of a GS1 codelist, you can easily switch in your MIG to a codelist from the GS1 Codelist Type System.
  • Additionally, the GS1 XML standard has defined four special complex types (ISO3166_1CodeType, ISO3166_2CodeType, ISO4217CodeType, and ISO639CodeType) to refer to the standard ISO Codes for Country, Subdivision, Currency, and Language. In Integration Advisor, their child elements (like countryISOCode) are automatically linked with the corresponding codelists from the ISO Codelists Type System.

Conclusion

With this content update, you can now build your Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs) and Mapping Guidelines (MAGs) based on the older versions of the GS1 XML Message Standard. You get an end-to-end solution, where you can view and customize GS1 XML messages in Integration Advisor and process such messages in Cloud Integration.

Further reading

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/overview-of-b2b-standards 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/integration-advisor-gs1-xml-messages-and-namespace-support/ba-p/13570459 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/integration-advisor-now-gs1-global-codelists-library-available/ba-p/13534622 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/using-edi-envelopes-in-integration-advisor/ba-p/13915328 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/integration-advisor-overview-of-components-for-building-b2b-integration/ba-p/13512772 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/integration-content-advisor-create-a-customized-interface-using-mig-editor/ba-p/13354699

entry.title: Re: How to configure Withholding Tax code 197A Exemption...
entry.content:
You can configure this requirement in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by defining two separate Withholding Tax Codes under Section 197A, each with its own threshold and rate. One code will apply 0.7% up to ₹2 crore, and the other will apply 1% above ₹2 crore. The system allows you to set minimum/maximum amounts and cumulative thresholds at the vendor level to automate this.

Follow the below steps

1. Define Withholding Tax Type
Create or use an existing Withholding Tax Type for Section 197A. Ensure it is linked to the relevant company code and jurisdiction. This type will act as the umbrella under which multiple tax codes are defined.

2. Create two Withholding Tax Codes
Tax Code 1 @ 0.7%. Maximum cumulative threshold: ₹2 crore. This ensures the system applies 0.7% only until the supplier’s payments reach ₹2 crore.

Tax Code 2 @ 1%. Minimum cumulative threshold: ₹2 crore + 1. This ensures the higher rate applies once the threshold is crossed. SAP documentation Overview of Settings for Withholding Tax  confirms that you can configure minimum and maximum amounts within WHT codes to enforce thresholds.

3. Assign Withholding Tax Type/Code to Supplier Master
In Business Partner Master Data, assign the relevant WHT type and codes to suppliers who fall under Section 197A. This ensures the system automatically applies the correct rate depending on cumulative payments.

4. Activate Threshold Tracking
SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud supports cumulative threshold tracking per vendor annually. This means the system will monitor payments across the financial year and switch from 0.7% to 1% once the ₹2 crore threshold is breached.

5. Testing & Validation
Post a test invoice below ₹2 crore → system should apply 0.7%. Post invoices cumulatively exceeding ₹2 crore → system should automatically switch to 1%. Validate in Withholding Tax Reporting to ensure compliance.

Please take the below as Key considerations

  • Scope Item Activation: Ensure the scope item for Extended Withholding Tax (1J2) is activated in your tenant.
  • Annual Reset: Thresholds reset at the start of each financial year, so configuration must align with Indian statutory requirements.
  • Supplier-Specific: Apply only to suppliers eligible under Section 197A; others may need different codes (e.g., 194C, 194J).

entry.title: Canada T4A-NR 2025 Regulatory Changes: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance(DRC)
entry.content:
Towards the end of 2025, the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) rolled out updates to the T4A-NR slip, summary forms, and the T619 XML schema. These changes, which will affect filings due on or before the last day of February 2026, have been seamlessly integrated into SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solutions, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition /On-Premise. Here’s a detailed look at what these updates entail and how SAP is ensuring compliance.

Key Regulatory Changes

  1. Updated CRA Forms: The CRA has released new 2025 versions of the T4A-NR slip and the T4A-NR Summary (T4A-NR-SUM) for the 2025 tax year. While the content changes are minimal, using the correct form version is essential to avoid filing issues.
  2. T619 XML Schema Updates:
    • Mandatory Language Code: To ensure consistent language identification for CRA communications, the T619 electronic transmittal now requires a language code to specify English or French, denoted by “E” or “F” for every submission. Previously optional, this field is now mandatory for 2025 filings.
    • No Empty Fields in XML: A new validation rule mandates that any optional XML element with no data must be omitted entirely. This means if a data field doesn’t apply or is blank, the system should not generate that XML tag at all, as including empty tags can lead to file rejection by the CRA. 

SAP's Support of Regulatory Changes

As part ofSAP’s end-to-end compliance vision, the SAP Globalization Product Management team has proactively delivered the necessary updates to accommodate these CRA changes, to ensure that customers can generate compliant T4A-NR slips, summaries, and XML files across SAP Cloud ERP solutions:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: The T4A-NR form and summary Adobe print forms have been updated in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to match the CRA’s 2025 PDF layout. Electronic filing content for T4A-NR has been enhanced to output XML according to the new schema, delivered via the regular quarterly release.
  •  SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition/On-Premise: SAP Note 3691523 – “Canada T4A-NR Withholding Tax Reporting: Legal Changes 2025” was released, along with a support package containing the updated forms and electronic report definitions. Applying this note or support pack will ensure the system produces the correct 2025 forms and XML.

Next Steps 

  • Review and Implement SAP Update: Ensure your SAP S/4HANA system has the 2025 year-end legal change for T4A-NR applied. For SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, apply SAP Note 3691523. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud, confirm you’re on the latest release that includes the T4A-NR changes. Implement these updates before year-end processing.
  • Test Your Reporting: Generate a sample T4A-NR slip, summary, and XML file in a test environment. Verify that the slip and summary display “2025” and the latest form text. Ensure the language element is present and correctly set, and confirm that there are no empty tags in the file.
  • Consult CRA Resources: Refer to the CRA’s official XML specifications page for the updated schema download and guidance for 2025/2026 filings. The CRA’s T4A-NR guide (RC4445) for 2025, updated December 2025, is also a helpful reference. Links to the schema files and CRA documentation are available on the CRA website.

Call to Action

SAP customers and partners can avoid last-minute scrambles and ensure a smooth tax filing season by taking the following actions:

  • Review our published "What's New" SAP Help Portal documentation, apply, and test the delivered SAP changes promptly.
  • Engage your IT or SAP support team to confirm that your system is outputting the new form and schema correctly. Leverage the Regulatory Change Manager for agility in adapting to new legal requirements.
  • Visit the CRA’s XML specification page for the official schema and test your files against it. With proper preparation, you’ll be ready to file your 2025 T4A‑NR returns without issues.
  • Connect with us via the SAP support channels or Canada Localization Workzone if questions arise during this update process.

entry.title: AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Practical Implementation Blueprint
entry.content:
Implementing AI in SAP SuccessFactors in 2026: A Practical, Customer-Ready Roadmap

From Strategy → Activation → Adoption → Scale

 

Key Takeaways (Please take a moment to read this first)

  • AI in SuccessFactors is not one switch. Treat it as Joule + embedded module AI + (optionally) Joule Studio extensions.
  • Do not start with configuration. Start with 5 to 10 prioritized use cases, persona-based KPIs, and a risk rating.
  • RBP is the real bottleneck. If permissions are wrong, adoption fails (or security risk increases).
  • Skills intelligence (TIH) is often the fastest value path. But only if job architecture + skills governance are ready.
  • Governance is non-negotiable in 2026. Human-in-the-loop, auditability, and privacy readiness prevent AI from getting paused.
  • Pilot with evidence-based gates. Scale only after metrics prove value and guardrails.

Table of Contents

  • Executive Summary
  • 1) Defining “AI in SuccessFactors” for 2026
  • 2) The #1 Mistake: Technology-First Thinking
  • 3) Commercial & Platform Readiness (Before Configuration)
  • 4) Technical Prerequisites & Architectural Readiness
  • 5) Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) AI: Fastest Path to Measurable Value
  • 6) The 8-Phase Implementation Roadmap
  • 7) Governance You Must Have in 2026 (Or AI Will Get Paused)
  • Adoption Challenges & Failure Recovery Paths
  • 9) Timelines & Resource Requirements
  • 10) What to Communicate to Leadership
  • Conclusion
  • Appendix: Quick Reference Templates
  • One-Page Implementation Checklist

Executive Summary

This guide translates SAP SuccessFactors AI capabilities into a disciplined, evidence-based implementation path. It addresses the critical gap between technical deployment and organizational value realization—where most initiatives stall. The framework balances strategic depth (architectural decisions, licensing, data governance) with pragmatic adoption mechanics (change management, pilot gates, skills lifecycle governance).

Key Premise: AI success is determined 40% by change management, 25% by technology, and 35% by data readiness & organizational alignment. Technical enablement is necessary, not sufficient.

1) Defining “AI in SuccessFactors” for 2026

SAP’s AI strategy in SuccessFactors operates across three integrated layers. Understanding the boundaries and dependencies between layers is essential for licensing, governance, and adoption planning.

Layer A: Joule — The Conversational AI Copilot

What it is: A role-aware conversational interface embedded across SuccessFactors, running on SAP BTP. Joule understands user role, context, and permissions, then helps employees navigate, retrieve information, and complete tasks through natural language.

Conversational patterns (all three are supported):

  • Navigation: “How do I access my compensation statement?”
  • Transactions: “Create a time-off request for Feb 10–14”
  • Information retrieval: “What’s my manager’s approval status on my promotion?”

Security Strength: Joule respects Role-Based Permissions (RBP) boundaries. It cannot return data a user should not see—even if requested. This requires careful RBP design (covered in Section 4).

2026 roadmap (example set): Performance & Goals Agent, Career & Talent Development Agent, People Intelligence Agent, HR Service Agent, Payroll Agent.

Strategic signal: Accelerating shift from traditional UI to conversational interaction.

Layer B: Embedded AI Features Inside Modules

These are AI capabilities tightly integrated into specific SuccessFactors modules. They don’t require Joule but add intelligence to traditional workflows.

  • Recruiting: AI-assisted job description generation, candidate scoring
  • Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH): Skill extraction, skill inferencing, skill standardization
  • Performance & Goals: Writing assistance, goal feedback suggestions
  • Learning: Course recommendations
  • Succession & Talent Development: Internal mobility recommendations

Licensing reality: Most embedded AI features require premium licensing (often via AI Units). Base SuccessFactors includes limited AI functionality.

Layer C: Extending AI with Joule Studio

What it is: A low-code, visual builder (part of SAP Build) for creating custom Joule skills and agents.

  • Skills: Deterministic, structured tasks (e.g., standardize job level from a requisition)
  • Agents: Multi-step, goal-oriented workflows requiring judgment (e.g., recommend internal candidates for a role)

When to use: When Layers A and B don’t cover differentiating workflows. Plan this later (typically Phase 7).

2) The #1 Mistake Customers Make: Technology-First Thinking

The common pattern: enable Joule, configure TIH, launch… then adoption plateaus and investment doesn’t scale. Root cause is prioritizing technology over outcomes, change management, and data readiness.

Outcome-Focused Use-Case Framework (by Persona)

Employees (Self-Service)

  • “How do I…?” questions grounded in HR policies and navigation
  • Policy Q&A with escalation paths
  • Content support: resume help, goal drafting, learning recommendations
  • Guardrails: AI should not make talent decisions (promotion, pay) without escalation

Managers

  • Coaching assistance (draft feedback, goal coaching)
  • People questions with proper authorization
  • Succession and development recommendations (permission-aware)
  • Guardrails: AI suggests; managers decide; recommendations labeled AI-assisted

HR / Centers of Expertise

  • Skills intelligence for planning (trending skills, gaps)
  • Internal mobility insights
  • Recruiting productivity improvements
  • Analytics-style Q&A (where available)

Governance integrity requirement: AI-assisted decisions (pay, promotion, termination) must be human-reviewed and documented.

Use-Case Scorecard (Phase 0 Deliverable)

Attribute Example

Use CasePolicy Q&A for employees
PersonaEmployee, all levels
Target Population5,000 active users
Data DependenciesHR policies + org structure
Risk RatingLow (informational)
KPIDAU 30% in 6 months; support ticket reduction 15%
Adoption BarrierTrust in answer accuracy
MitigationChampion loop + escalation path

3) Commercial & Platform Readiness (Before Configuration)

Principle: Understand licensing obligations and data governance constraints before building. Changing course mid-implementation is costly.

3.1 AI Units Licensing: The 2026 Reality

Premium AI capabilities are commonly packaged and consumed via AI Units. Establish consumption governance early to avoid budget surprises.

Feature AI Units Required? Notes

Joule (copilot/agents)Yes (Premium)Interactions may consume AI Units (validate per contract)
TIH advanced AI (extraction/inferencing)Yes (Premium)Advanced TIH capabilities typically require AI Units
Writing assistance (basic)Often NoMay be included depending on edition / scope

Budgeting recommendation: baseline consumption in pilot, model scale-up, implement approvals for premium feature enablement, and budget contingency for usage creep.

3.2 Regional Compliance & Data Residency

If you operate across borders (especially EU/UK), data residency and cross-border processing obligations can impact timeline and design. Start legal/privacy work early (privacy impact assessment, DPA updates, audit expectations).

4) Technical Prerequisites & Architectural Readiness

Principle: Joule and TIH integration requires alignment across SuccessFactors, SAP Cloud Identity Services, and SAP BTP.

4.1 Three-Pillar Infrastructure

  • Pillar 1: SAP SuccessFactors — release readiness, platform configuration, RBP maturity
  • Pillar 2: SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) — authentication, SSO, provisioning
  • Pillar 3: SAP BTP — foundation for Joule services, setup automation/boosters, integrations

Project reality check: This is cross-platform, not only SuccessFactors. Plan admin roles and ownership across HR, IT, Identity, and Security.

4.2 Role-Based Permissions (RBP): The Strategic Bottleneck

RBP is not a checkbox. It is the mechanism that determines what Joule can show and do for each user. If RBP is too permissive, you risk exposure. If too restrictive, adoption collapses.

RBP Architecture (Three-Element Framework)

  • Permission Groups (static/dynamic)
  • Permission Roles (bundled permissions)
  • Target Populations (data scoping)

RBP Implementation Sequence (Industry Standard)

Phase Duration Key Activities Owner

Design3–4 weeksStakeholder interviews, role/target modelHR/IT/Security
Build2–3 weeksConfigure groups/roles/targetsSF Admin/RBP Specialist
Test3–4 weeksPersona testing, SoD checks, edge casesQA/Security/Compliance
Deploy1–2 weeksRulebook, admin training, go-liveProject Team
OngoingContinuousMonthly governance + quarterly auditIT Ops/Internal Audit

4.3 Joule Onboarding Pathway (Technical Activation)

  1. Run BTP setup (booster-led or guided): provision Joule services and validate connectivity
  2. Enable “Access to Joule” via RBP: start with pilot groups
  3. Execute the guided mission/setup steps: complete configuration and testing scenarios
  4. Validate user experience: confirm Joule is visible for pilot users; test permission boundaries

5) Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) AI: The Fastest Path to Measurable Value

If you want measurable HR outcomes (hiring speed, internal mobility, workforce planning), TIH is often the best starting point because it connects skills intelligence to real HR decisions and workflows.

What TIH AI Does

  • Skill Extraction: from job profiles, requisitions, resumes; creates normalized skills library
  • Skill Inferencing: infers skills from activities/achievements/feedback; recommends to employees
  • Standardization & Governance: deduplicate and manage taxonomy; govern lifecycle inferred → confirmed

The Skills Governance Workflow (Critical)

  1. Enable TIH AI capabilities in admin configuration
  2. Run initial extraction and build skills library
  3. Review and standardize: merge duplicates; build taxonomy
  4. Enable inferencing and define decision rules
  5. Establish cadence: monthly review; quarterly audit; annual refresh

Most common failure: “We’ll clean job architecture later.” Dirty job architecture produces low-quality skill signals and user distrust. Clean critical job architecture inputs before scaling TIH AI.

6) The 8-Phase Implementation Roadmap

Core principle: Each phase has success criteria and decision gates. Scale only when evidence supports it.

Phase 0: AI Readiness Assessment (Weeks 1–2)

  • Top 5 use cases + KPIs
  • Data maturity assessment (job architecture, org graph quality, skills readiness)
  • Privacy & compliance assessment
  • High-level architecture sketch (SF ↔ IAS ↔ BTP ↔ Joule)
  • Pilot scope and exit criteria

Phase 1: Commercial & Entitlements (Weeks 3–5)

  • Confirm premium AI needs and consumption governance
  • Confirm region/data residency constraints
  • Finalize legal/DPA requirements

Phase 2: Identity & Access Foundation (Weeks 6–11)

  • IAS readiness (or migration as needed)
  • RBP design/build/test and security sign-off
  • Pilot user groups defined
  • Audit/logging expectations documented

Phase 3: Core Joule Onboarding (Weeks 12–14)

  • Provision Joule services
  • Enable Access to Joule for pilot group
  • Validate guardrails + audit readiness
  • UAT with pilot personas

Phase 4: “Safe Pilot” Launch (12-week pilot)

  • Controlled rollout to 100–500 users
  • Track DAU, helpfulness, escalations, support tickets, sentiment
  • Decision gate: Go / Hold / Pause and redesign

Phase 5: Skills Intelligence Activation (TIH) (4-week intensive + ongoing)

  • Enable extraction + inferencing
  • Standardize taxonomy
  • Establish monthly governance cadence

Phase 6: Premium AI Use-Case Expansion (Weeks 43–52)

  • Expand to new BUs/regions only after pilot evidence
  • Implement monthly usage governance + ROI tracking

Phase 7: Extend with Joule Studio (Optional) (8–16 weeks)

  • Build custom skills/agents for differentiating workflows
  • Security review + edge case testing

Phase 8: Operate, Monitor & Continuously Improve (Ongoing)

  • Weekly ops review
  • Monthly adoption + consumption review
  • Quarterly roadmap alignment
  • Annual ROI assessment

7) Governance You Must Have in 2026 (Or AI Will Get Paused)

7.1 Responsible AI Framework (Non-Negotiable)

Control Implementation Owner

Human-in-the-LoopTalent-impacting decisions require human approval and documentationHR + Managers
Audit TrailsLog who asked what, outputs, approvals, and actions; align retention policyIT + Compliance
Data MinimizationOnly use the data needed; restrict sensitive fields unless requiredData Architect
Bias/Outcome ReviewQuarterly audits to detect disparate impact and remediateHR Analytics + Compliance
Escalation ProtocolDefine triggers for HR Legal/Compliance escalationHR Legal

7.2 Lightweight AI Center of Excellence (COE)

  • HR Product Owner: value + adoption
  • SF Platform Lead: configuration + RBP + release planning
  • BTP/Identity Lead: IAS + BTP operations
  • Governance/Compliance: audit + privacy + controls
  • Change Manager: enablement + comms + feedback loops

Adoption Challenges & Failure Recovery Paths

Failure Mode 1: Pilot Success, Scale Stall

  • Root causes: sheltered pilot population, uneven data quality by region, change management not scalable, guardrails misfit
  • Recovery: pause expansion, diagnose by cohort, fix root causes, phased rollout with monitoring gates

Failure Mode 2: Skills Governance Breakdown

  • Root causes: dirty job architecture, unclear ownership, inconsistent approval rules
  • Recovery: pause, clean taxonomy, define decision rules, assign ownership and cadence

Failure Mode 3: RBP Security Incident

  • Root causes: misconfigured target populations
  • Recovery: disable, audit access, fix RBP, retest, add monthly RBP audit

Failure Mode 4: Budget Overage & Licensing Surprise

  • Root causes: usage creep, adoption growth, unplanned premium features
  • Recovery: analyze consumption drivers, prioritize ROI, throttle low-ROI features, strengthen approval governance

9) Realistic Timelines & Resource Requirements

Overall Timeline (Typical)

Phase Duration Key Resource Gap

Phase 02 weeksProgram manager + architect
Phase 13 weeksProcurement + finance alignment
Phase 26 weeksRBP specialist
Phase 33 weeksSF admin + IT
Phase 412 weeksChange leadership + pilot champions
Phase 54 weeks + ongoingData/skills governance owner
Phase 64 weeksOps + governance scale
Phase 7 (optional)8–16 weeksSAP Build developer
Phase 8OngoingLean COE

10) What to Communicate to Leadership (Executive Summary)

The Business Case (Illustrative)

  • HR productivity: 10–15% reduction in operations time
  • Manager effectiveness: shift time from admin to coaching
  • Internal mobility: increase internal fills via skills visibility and recommendations

The Risk Summary

Risk Likelihood Mitigation

Adoption stallsModerateInvest in change management; evidence-based gates
Data quality issues at scaleModeratePhase 0 data assessment; clean job architecture
RBP misconfigurationLow if Phase 2 done wellDo not skip RBP testing; monthly audit
Budget overageModerateConsumption governance; ROI-based enablement
Compliance gapLow with governancePrivacy assessment + audit trails + HitL

Conclusion

Implementing AI in SuccessFactors is not primarily a technology problem; it is an organizational change and data readiness problem. Technical enablement is table stakes. The decisive factors are:

  • Change management rigor (drives adoption)
  • Data readiness (drives answer and recommendation quality)
  • Technology execution (enables secure, scalable experiences)

Start with Phase 0. Don’t skip Phase 2 (RBP). Invest in change management throughout.

Appendix: Quick Reference Templates

Phase 0 Use-Case Scorecard (Template)

Target Population: [# of users]

Guardrails Validated | All pass | ___ | ___ | ✓/✗

RBP Design Worksheet (Template)

Sales Reps | Employee | Dept=Sales | View own records; access company policies | [Name] | Draft

One-Page Implementation Checklist

Use this as a program control sheet. The goal is to avoid “pilot excitement” turning into “scale failure.”

Workstream            Checklist Item                                               Exit Criteria                                                                  Owner                             Status

entry.title: Re: Assignment to a profitability segment has no effect f...
entry.content:
To get details about (and options for) submitting your questions to SAP Community, please see the Asking and Answering Questions in the Community After Migration post in the What's New section. You may also want to watch How do I ask a question from a category page?, as this how-to video illustrates one approach for posting a question to SAP Community.
Before you ask a question, please browse the community in case this question has been answered already.
If you need to create a new question, start with a descriptive title that briefly outlines what your question is about. A clear question title will help community members gain a quick initial understanding of your question. It will also help community members find your question (and its answers) when they are searching for solutions to similar problems.
When writing your question, please share what steps you took that led you to your question. If you don't, community members might tell you to take actions you've already tried yourself.
Make sure that your question is very specific. Provide as many details as you can -- such as which product version you are using and what error message you're receiving. Include screenshots if possible.

Since you have not indicated in which version you are working ( ECC or S/4HANA), check SAP note 3562180 (if yours is S/4) and see whether you need to carry out code corrections as recommended in this note.

entry.content:

We are using the standard Manage My Timesheet Fiori application in SAP S/4HANA 2023 On-Premise.
Now I have a requirement to extend this standard app using a SAPUI5 Adaptation Project in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS).

 

Requirement
I need to implement custom UI logic so that the Draft mode is automatically enabled whenever the user starts creating or editing a timesheet entry.

Currently, users must manually click the “Enable Draft” checkbox, which is often missed.

Questions
Is it possible to extend the standard Timesheet app (Manage My Timesheet) using a SAPUI5 Adaptation Project for an on-premise S/4HANA system?

After adapting the UI in BAS, can we deploy the variant back to the on-premise ABAP repository?

Do we need to configure SAP Cloud Connector + BTP Destination for BAS to access the on-premise S/4 system?

Is the controller extension the correct place to implement logic for auto-enabling Draft mode?

Are there any known limitations or best practices when using an adaptation project specifically for the Timesheet application?

My Understanding (Please Confirm)
Adaptation Projects are supported for S/4HANA on-premise if prerequisites (SAP_UI version, UI5 version, no scaffolding app, etc.) are fulfilled.

Deployment requires an ABAP package and Transport Request.

BAS requires system connectivity through Cloud Connector + Destination using

Controller extension should allow injecting custom logic to auto-enable draft mode.

Info about timesheet ;

Title  : My Timesheet
ID       :F3074A
Version  : 12.3.25
Component  : PA-FIO-TS
Technical Component ID  : hcm.fio.mytimesheets1
Framework ID : UI5
Framework Version : 1.120.23 (202411061204)

Request
Before setting up Cloud Connector and BTP Destinations, I want to confirm whether this approach is the correct and supported way to enhance the Timesheet app, and whether anyone has implemented similar customizations.

Any guidance, confirmation, or documentation reference would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

Arbaj Shekh

entry.title: Re: Using XDL to purge data from Stage Tables in SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management
entry.content:
We implemented it like: a data extract provides us with a file in Pipeline-template format containing all batches in stage in which are older than x days. we pick up the file, delete all rows which exceed a tbd limit (e.g. 20) and put the file back to the inbound dropbox. Then 20 purge pipelines are triggered. 
As long as the limit is higher than your average number of files which you load per day, you will see that you end up in a stage-table history which is not exceeding the x days.
